content:
Existentialism does not necessarily reject objective truth altogether. Rather, it questions the certainty and completeness of objective truth.

Existentialists believe that individuals experience and interpret the world subjectively, based on their unique perspectives and experiences. This subjectivity means that objective truth, as traditionally understood, may not capture the full complexity of human experience. Furthermore, existentialists argue that the very act of seeking objective truth can be an attempt to escape the uncertainties and anxieties of existence.

Instead of seeking objective truth, existentialism emphasizes the importance of personal experience and individual interpretation in shaping our understanding of the world. By embracing the inevitability of uncertainty and ambiguity, individuals can discover new ways of being in the world that are not limited by traditional notions of objective truth.

It is important to note that existentialism does not reject the idea of shared understanding altogether, but rather it emphasizes that individuals must take responsibility for their own understanding of reality, even as they communicate and collaborate with others. In this way, existentialism seeks to promote a more authentic, insightful, and engaged form of human existence.
